0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Hysterosalpingography: increments of 2 mL INTRA-ENDOMETRIAL INJECTION until tubal patency determined
  • Imaging of liver: 1.5 to 15 mL via slow INTRA-ARTERIAL INJECTION with continuous radiologic monitoring; MAX, 20 mL
  • Lymphadenogram: unilateral lymphography of upper extremities, 2 to 4 mL via INTRALYMPHATIC CHANNEL INJECTION
  • Lymphadenogram: unilateral lymphography of lower extremities, 6 to 8 mL via INTRALYMPHATIC CHANNEL INJECTION
  • Lymphadenogram: penile lymphography, 2 to 3 mL via INTRALYMPHATIC CHANNEL INJECTION
  • Lymphadenogram: cervical lymphography of upper extremities, 1 to 2 mL via INTRALYMPHATIC CHANNEL INJECTION

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: Lymphadenogram: MIN of 1 mL to MAX of 6 mL via INTRALYMPHATIC CHANNEL INJECTION, based on anatomical area for imaging; MAX 0.25 mL/kg

mono.title: Black Box Warning
mono.mono:
Injection (Oil)
Inadvertent intravascular injection or intravasation of ethiodized oil may cause pulmonary and cerebral embolism. Inject slowly with radiologic monitoring; do not exceed recommended dose.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to ethiodized oil
  • hyperthyroidism
  • recent bleeding or hemorrhage
  • trauma
  • Hepatocellular Carcinoma, Selected Hepatic Intraarterial Use:
  • -- areas of bile duct dilation without pretreatment external biliary drainage
  • Hysterosalpingography:
  • -- acute pelvic inflammatory disease
  • -- endocervicitis and intrauterine bleeding
  • -- phase immediately before or after menstruation
  • -- interval within 30 days of curettage or conization
  • -- marked cervical erosion
  • -- pregnancy
  • Lymphography:
  • -- advanced neoplastic disease with expected lymphatic obstruction
  • -- advanced pulmonary disease
  • -- previous surgery that causes lymphatic system interruption
  • -- radiation therapy to the examined area
  • -- right to left cardiac shunt
  • -- tissue trauma or hemorrhage

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Black Box Warning:
  • -- pulmonary and cerebral embolism can occur with inadvertent intravascular injection or intravasation; monitoring recommended
  • Endocrine:
  • -- hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism may occur, with increased risk in patients with latent hyperthyroidism, Hashimoto thyroiditis, or history of thyroid irradiation
  • Hepatic:
  • -- life-threatening and fatal hepatic vein thrombosis and liver insufficiency have been reported
  • -- hepatic intraarterial administration may worsen portal hypertension or hepatic ischemia and induce fever, abdominal pain, variceal bleeds, liver enzyme elevations, ascites, encephalopathy, or hepatic failure
  • -- increased risk of vascular complications and infections with hepatic intraarterial administration
  • Immunologic:
  • -- life-threatening anaphylactoid and anaphylactic reactions have rarely occurred; monitoring recommended; avoid use in patients with a history of sensitivity to iodinated contrast agents, bronchial asthma, or allergic disorders
  • Neurologic:
  • -- cerebral embolism has been reported with inadvertent intravascular injection or intravasation; monitoring recommended; avoid use in patients with severe lung function impairment, cardiorespiratory failure, or right-sided cardiac overload
  • Respiratory:
  • -- pulmonary embolism has been reported with intravascular injection or intravasation, which may progress to life-threatening respiratory complications; monitoring recommended; avoid use in patients with severe lung function impairment, cardiorespiratory failure, or right-sided cardiac overload

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

mono.title: Adverse Effects
mono.mono:
Serious
  • Hepatic:Hepatic vein thrombosis, Liver failure
  • Immunologic:Anaphylactoid reaction, Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Neurologic:Cerebral embolism
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary embolism

mono.title: Mechanism Of Action
mono.mono: Ethiodized oil is an iodinated oil-based imaging agent that is distributed in the liver and remains for 2 to 4 weeks in healthy subjects and longer in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma, allowing for imaging and re-imaging weeks after administration.

mono.title: Administration
mono.mono:
Injection
  • use glass syringe for administration and use promptly
  • discard unused drug
  • hepatic intra-arterial injection: administer slowly with continuous radiologic monitoring; discontinue with evidence of stagnation or reflux
  • lymphography: use frequent radiologic monitoring to assess administration rate and follow lymphatic progression
  • lymphography: inject no faster than 0.2 mL/min, but inject total dose over of minimum of 1.25 hours
  • lymphography: interrupt administration if patient has pain; discontinue administration if ethiodized oil is observed in thoracic duct or with lymphatic blockage

mono.title: Monitoring
mono.mono:
• adequate visualization of hysterosalpingography, lymphography, or hepatocellular carcinoma tumors indicate efficacy
  • renal dysfunction; in all patients prior to intraarterial administration
  • renal function; consider followup assessment in patients with history of renal dysfunction
